text: Foundational truth: develop skills systematically to build a valuable career asset.
Contrast maxim: passion without skill development leads to unfulfilled aspirations.
IF  THEN Action criterion: continuously develop skills to increase career capital.
IF  THEN Operational test: evaluate career potential through skill mastery rather than passion alone.
CLAIM: Skills directly enable the acquisition of desirable work conditions.
CLAIM: Career capital can be leveraged for creative, autonomous work.
Avoid passion-driven career decisions based on immediate feelings.
Focus on mastery and skill development as the foundation for career satisfaction.
IF  THEN Develop expertise before seeking career advancement.
IF  THEN Progress through jobs before pursuing a calling.
CLAIM: Passion is a side-effect of mastery, not a primary driver.
CLAIM: Craftsman mindset leads to career clarity and fulfillment.
Value creation through skill development leads to desired outcomes.
Continuous self-improvement is essential for career growth.
IF  THEN Develop rare and valuable skills to obtain career capital.
IF  THEN Trade career capital for control and influence.
IF  THEN Avoid promotions that reduce control if they haven't built sufficient career capital.
IF  THEN Seek 'open gates' to build career capital by focusing on opportunities that align with personal strengths.
CLAIM: Serious study is the greatest predictor of success, outweighing tournament play.
CLAIM: Deliberate practice is necessary for significant improvement, even if it is not enjoyable.
Focus on a core purpose for career direction
Embrace gradual progress and skill development
Test ideas incrementally through small experiments
IF  THEN Build foundational skills before pursuing major goals
IF  THEN Cash in professional capital for increased control and flexibility
CLAIM: Pursuing passion without a defined mission leads to dissatisfaction
CLAIM: Remarkable work naturally attracts attention and support
